title: Nakano, Nagano
text:
is a <a href="Cities%20of%20Japan">city</a> located in <a href="Nagano%20Prefecture">Nagano Prefecture</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>. , the city had an estimated <a href="population">population</a> of 42,664 in 15649 households, and a <a href="population%20density">population density</a> of 380 persons per km². The total area of the city is .
Geography.
Located in the northern end of the Zennoji Plain of northern Nagano prefecture, Nakano is located on the <a href="Chikuma%20River">Chikuma River</a> and is surrounded by mountains. The weather in Nakano varies greatly over the seasons.
Demographics.
Per Japanese census data, the population of Nakano remained relatively constant over the past 60 years.
Climate.
Nakano has a climate characterized by characterized by hot and humid summers, and relatively mild winters (<a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen climate classification</a> "Cfa"). The average annual temperature in Nakano is 12.2 °C. The average annual rainfall is 1406 mm with September as the wettest month. The temperatures are highest on average in August, at around 25.6 °C, and lowest in January, at around -0.4 °C.
History.
The area of present-day Nakano was part of ancient <a href="Shinano%20Province">Shinano Province</a>. The area was part of the "<a href="tenry%C5%8D">tenryō</a>" (direct holdings) of the <a href="Tokugawa%20shogunate">Tokugawa shogunate</a> during the <a href="Edo%20period">Edo period</a> and was administered from Nakano "<a href="jin%27ya">jin'ya</a>." Nakano was the capital of "Nakano Prefecture" form 1870 to 1871, when it was merged with Nagano Prefecture. The modern town of Nakano was established on April 1, 1889 with the establishment of the municipalities system. It was elevated to city status on July 1, 1955 by the merger of the town with neighboring villages of Hino, Entoku, Nagaoka, Hiraoka, Takaoka, Shinano, and Yamato.
On April 1, 2005, the village of <a href="Toyota%2C%20Nagano">Toyota</a> (from <a href="Shimominochi%20District%2C%20Nagano">Shimominochi District</a>) was merged into Nakano.
Government.
Nakano has a <a href="mayor-council">mayor-council</a> form of government with a directly elected mayor and a <a href="unicameral">unicameral</a> city legislature of 20 members.
Economy.
The city of Nakano is supported largely by its agricultural industry. Nakano boasts high quality fruits and vegetables, including <a href="Fuji%20apple">Fuji apple</a>s, Kyohō grapes, peaches, pears, rice, asparagus, and mushrooms. It is Japan's largest producer of "<a href="Enokitake">Enokitake</a>" mushrooms. The city is also well known for its <a href="rose">rose</a>s. The biannual rose festival in Ippongi Park displays thousands of rose plants, and attracts tourists from all over Japan. Nakano City has experienced significant growth since the Nagano <a href="1998%20Winter%20Olympics">1998 Winter Olympics</a>. Located near many popular ski areas, Nakano's economy is augmented by the ski-tourism industry.
Nakano is home to <a href="Cosina">Cosina Co., Ltd</a>, a designer and manufacturer of camera and lenses.
Education.
Nakano has 11 public elementary schools and four public middle schools run by the city. There are two public high schools under the Nagano Prefectural Board of Education.
Local attractions.
Sports teams.
In 2007, Nakano became home to the Shinano Grand Serows, a baseball team in the Japanese BC League (<a href="Baseball%20Challenge%20League">Baseball Challenge League</a>).
